column2: Then good-bye and good-bye, and charming occasion worthy of the Golden Age, and more about the flitch of bacon, and the like of that; and Twemlow goes staggering across Piccadilly with his hand to his forehead, and is nearly run down by a flushed lettercart, and at last drops safe in his easy-chair, innocent good gentleman, with his hand to his forehead still, and his head in a whirl.
column3: Then good bye and good bye, and charming occasion worthy of the Golden Age, and more about the flitch of bacon, and the like of that; and Twemlow goes staggering across Piccadilly with his hand to his forehead, and is nearly run down by a flushed lettercart, and at last drops safe in his easy chair, innocent good gentleman, with his hand to his forehead still, and his head in a whirl.

column2: BOOK THE THIRD -- A LONG LANE

column2: Chapter 1
column3: Chapter one

column2: LODGERS IN QUEER STREET
column3: LODGERS IN QUEER STREET

column2: It was a foggy day in London, and the fog was heavy and dark.
column3: It was a foggy day in London, and the fog was heavy and dark.

column2: Animate London, with smarting eyes and irritated lungs, was blinking, wheezing, and choking; inanimate London was a sooty spectre, divided in purpose between being visible and invisible, and so being wholly neither. Gaslights flared in the shops with a haggard and unblest air, as knowing themselves to be night-creatures that had no business abroad under the sun; while the sun itself when it was for a few moments dimly indicated through circling eddies of fog, showed as if it had gone out and were collapsing flat and cold.
column3: Animate London, with smarting eyes and irritated lungs, was blinking, wheezing, and choking; inanimate London was a sooty spectre, divided in purpose between being visible and invisible, and so being wholly neither. Gaslights flared in the shops with a haggard and unblest air, as knowing themselves to be night creatures that had no business abroad under the sun; while the sun itself when it was for a few moments dimly indicated through circling eddies of fog, showed as if it had gone out and were collapsing flat and cold.

column2: Even in the surrounding country it was a foggy day, but there the fog was grey, whereas in London it was, at about the boundary line, dark yellow, and a little within it brown, and then browner, and then browner, until at the heart of the City--which call Saint Mary Axe--it was rusty-black.
column3: Even in the surrounding country it was a foggy day, but there the fog was grey, whereas in London it was, at about the boundary line, dark yellow, and a little within it brown, and then browner, and then browner, until at the heart of the City-which call Saint Mary Axe-it was rusty black.

column2: From any point of the high ridge of land northward, it might have been discerned that the loftiest buildings made an occasional struggle to get their heads above the foggy sea, and especially that the great dome of Saint Paul's seemed to die hard; but this was not perceivable in the streets at their feet, where the whole metropolis was a heap of vapour charged with muffled sound of wheels, and enfolding a gigantic catarrh.
column3: From any point of the high ridge of land northward, it might have been discerned that the loftiest buildings made an occasional struggle to get their heads above the foggy sea, and especially that the great dome of Saint Paul's seemed to die hard; but this was not perceivable in the streets at their feet, where the whole metropolis was a heap of vapour charged with muffled sound of wheels, and enfolding a gigantic catarrh.

column2: At nine o'clock on such a morning, the place of business of Pubsey and Co. was not the liveliest object even in Saint Mary Axe--which is not a very lively spot--with a sobbing gaslight in the counting-house window, and a burglarious stream of fog creeping in to strangle it through the keyhole of the main door.
column3: At nine o'clock on such a morning, the place of business of Pubsey and Co. was not the liveliest object even in Saint Mary Axe-which is not a very lively spot-with a sobbing gaslight in the counting house window, and a burglarious stream of fog creeping in to strangle it through the keyhole of the main door.

column2: But the light went out, and the main door opened, and Riah came forth with a bag under his arm.
column3: But the light went out, and the main door opened, and Riah came forth with a bag under his arm.

column2: Almost in the act of coming out at the door, Riah went into the fog, and was lost to the eyes of Saint Mary Axe.
column3: Almost in the act of coming out at the door, Riah went into the fog, and was lost to the eyes of Saint Mary Axe.

column2: But the eyes of this history can follow him westward, by Cornhill, Cheapside, Fleet Street, and the Strand, to Piccadilly and the Albany.
column3: But the eyes of this history can follow him westward, by Cornhill, Cheapside, Fleet Street, and the Strand, to Piccadilly and the Albany.

column2: Thither he went at his grave and measured pace, staff in hand, skirt at heel; and more than one head, turning to look back at his venerable figure already lost in the mist, supposed it to be some ordinary figure indistinctly seen, which fancy and the fog had worked into that passing likeness.
column3: Thither he went at his grave and measured pace, staff in hand, skirt at heel; and more than one head, turning to look back at his venerable figure already lost in the mist, supposed it to be some ordinary figure indistinctly seen, which fancy and the fog had worked into that passing likeness.

column2: Arrived at the house in which his master's chambers were on the second floor, Riah proceeded up the stairs, and paused at Fascination Fledgeby's door.
column3: Arrived at the house in which his master's chambers were on the second floor, Riah proceeded up the stairs, and paused at Fascination Fledgeby's door.

column2: Making free with neither bell nor knocker, he struck upon the door with the top of his staff, and, having listened, sat down on the threshold.
column3: Making free with neither bell nor knocker, he struck upon the door with the top of his staff, and, having listened, sat down on the threshold.

column2: It was characteristic of his habitual submission, that he sat down on the raw dark staircase, as many of his ancestors had probably sat down in dungeons, taking what befell him as it might befall.
column3: It was characteristic of his habitual submission, that he sat down on the raw dark staircase, as many of his ancestors had probably sat down in dungeons, taking what befell him as it might befall.

column2: After a time, when he had grown so cold as to be fain to blow upon his fingers, he arose and knocked with his staff again, and listened again, and again sat down to wait.
column3: After a time, when he had grown so cold as to be fain to blow upon his fingers, he arose and knocked with his staff again, and listened again, and again sat down to wait.

column2: Thrice he repeated these actions before his listening ears were greeted by the voice of Fledgeby, calling from his bed, 'Hold your row!--I'll come and open the door directly!' But, in lieu of coming directly, he fell into a sweet sleep for some quarter of an hour more, during which added interval Riah sat upon the stairs and waited with perfect patience.
column3: Thrice he repeated these actions before his listening ears were greeted by the voice of Fledgeby, calling from his bed, 'Hold your row!--I'll come and open the door directly!' But, in lieu of coming directly, he fell into a sweet sleep for some quarter of an hour more, during which added interval Riah sat upon the stairs and waited with perfect patience.

column2: At length the door stood open, and Mr Fledgeby's retreating drapery plunged into bed again.
column3: At length the door stood open, and Mr Fledgeby's retreating drapery plunged into bed again.

column2: Following it at a respectful distance, Riah passed into the bed-chamber, where a fire had been sometime lighted, and was burning briskly.
column3: Following it at a respectful distance, Riah passed into the bed chamber, where a fire had been sometime lighted, and was burning briskly.

column2: 'Why, what time of night do you mean to call it?' inquired Fledgeby, turning away beneath the clothes, and presenting a comfortable rampart of shoulder to the chilled figure of the old man.
column3: 'Why, what time of night do you mean to call it?' inquired Fledgeby, turning away beneath the clothes, and presenting a comfortable rampart of shoulder to the chilled figure of the old man.

column2: 'Sir, it is full half-past ten in the morning.'
column3: 'Sir, it is full half past ten in the morning.'

column2: 'The deuce it is!
column3: 'The deuce it is!

column2: Then it must be precious foggy?'
column3: Then it must be precious foggy?'

column2: 'Very foggy, sir.'
column3: 'Very foggy, sir.'

column2: 'And raw, then?'
column3: 'And raw, then?'

column2: 'Chill and bitter,' said Riah, drawing out a handkerchief, and wiping the moisture from his beard and long grey hair as he stood on the verge of the rug, with his eyes on the acceptable fire.
column3: 'Chill and bitter,' said Riah, drawing out a handkerchief, and wiping the moisture from his beard and long grey hair as he stood on the verge of the rug, with his eyes on the acceptable fire.

column2: With a plunge of enjoyment, Fledgeby settled himself afresh.
column3: With a plunge of enjoyment, Fledgeby settled himself afresh.

column2: 'Any snow, or sleet, or slush, or anything of that sort?' he asked.
column3: 'Any snow, or sleet, or slush, or anything of that sort?' he asked.

column2: 'No, sir, no. Not quite so bad as that.
column3: 'No, sir, no Not quite so bad as that.

column2: The streets are pretty clean.'
column3: The streets are pretty clean.'

column2: 'You needn't brag about it,' returned Fledgeby, disappointed in his desire to heighten the contrast between his bed and the streets.
column3: 'You needn't brag about it,' returned Fledgeby, disappointed in his desire to heighten the contrast between his bed and the streets.

column2: 'But you're always bragging about something.
column3: 'But you're always bragging about something.

column2: Got the books there?'
column3: Got the books there?'

column2: 'They are here, sir.'
column3: 'They are here, sir.'

column2: 'All right.
column3: 'All right.

column2: I'll turn the general subject over in my mind for a minute or two, and while I'm about it you can empty your bag and get ready for me.'
column3: I'll turn the general subject over in my mind for a minute or two, and while I'm about it you can empty your bag and get ready for me.'

column2: With another comfortable plunge, Mr Fledgeby fell asleep again.
column3: With another comfortable plunge, Mr Fledgeby fell asleep again.

column2: The old man, having obeyed his directions, sat down on the edge of a chair, and, folding his hands before him, gradually yielded to the influence of the warmth, and dozed.
column3: The old man, having obeyed his directions, sat down on the edge of a chair, and, folding his hands before him, gradually yielded to the influence of the warmth, and dozed.

column2: He was roused by Mr Fledgeby's appearing erect at the foot of the bed, in Turkish slippers, rose-coloured Turkish trousers (got cheap from somebody who had cheated some other somebody out of them), and a gown and cap to correspond.
column3: He was roused by Mr Fledgeby's appearing erect at the foot of the bed, in Turkish slippers, rose coloured Turkish trousers (got cheap from somebody who had cheated some other somebody out of them), and a gown and cap to correspond.

column2: In that costume he would have left nothing to be desired, if he had been further fitted out with a bottomless chair, a lantern, and a bunch of matches.
column3: In that costume he would have left nothing to be desired, if he had been further fitted out with a bottomless chair, a lantern, and a bunch of matches.

column2: 'Now, old 'un!' cried Fascination, in his light raillery, 'what dodgery are you up to next, sitting there with your eyes shut?
column3: 'Now, old 'un!' cried Fascination, in his light raillery, 'what dodgery are you up to next, sitting there with your eyes shut?

column2: You ain't asleep. Catch a weasel at it, and catch a Jew!'
column3: You ain't asleep. Catch a weasel at it, and catch a Jew!'

column2: 'Truly, sir, I fear I nodded,' said the old man.
column3: 'Truly, sir, I fear I nodded,' said the old man.

column2: 'Not you!' returned Fledgeby, with a cunning look.
column3: 'Not you!' returned Fledgeby, with a cunning look.

column2: 'A telling move with a good many, I dare say, but it won't put ME off my guard.
column3: 'A telling move with a good many, I dare say, but it won't put m e off my guard.

column2: Not a bad notion though, if you want to look indifferent in driving a bargain.
column3: Not a bad notion though, if you want to look indifferent in driving a bargain.

column2: Oh, you are a dodger!'
column3: Oh, you are a dodger!'

column2: The old man shook his head, gently repudiating the imputation, and suppressed a sigh, and moved to the table at which Mr Fledgeby was now pouring out for himself a cup of steaming and fragrant coffee from a pot that had stood ready on the hob.
column3: The old man shook his head, gently repudiating the imputation, and suppressed a sigh, and moved to the table at which Mr Fledgeby was now pouring out for himself a cup of steaming and fragrant coffee from a pot that had stood ready on the hob.

column2: It was an edifying spectacle, the young man in his easy chair taking his coffee, and the old man with his grey head bent, standing awaiting his pleasure.
column3: It was an edifying spectacle, the young man in his easy chair taking his coffee, and the old man with his grey head bent, standing awaiting his pleasure.

column2: 'Now!' said Fledgeby. 'Fork out your balance in hand, and prove by figures how you make it out that it ain't more.
column3: 'Now!' said Fledgeby. 'Fork out your balance in hand, and prove by figures how you make it out that it ain't more.

column2: First of all, light that candle.'
column3: First of all, light that candle.'

column2: Riah obeyed, and then taking a bag from his breast, and referring to the sum in the accounts for which they made him responsible, told it out upon the table.
column3: Riah obeyed, and then taking a bag from his breast, and referring to the sum in the accounts for which they made him responsible, told it out upon the table.

column2: Fledgeby told it again with great care, and rang every sovereign.
column3: Fledgeby told it again with great care, and rang every sovereign.

column2: 'I suppose,' he said, taking one up to eye it closely, 'you haven't been lightening any of these; but it's a trade of your people's, you know. YOU understand what sweating a pound means, don't you?'
column3: 'I suppose,' he said, taking one up to eye it closely, 'you haven't been lightening any of these; but it's a trade of your people's, you know. YOU understand what sweating a pound means, don't you?'

column2: 'Much as you do, sir,' returned the old man, with his hands under opposite cuffs of his loose sleeves, as he stood at the table, deferentially observant of the master's face.
column3: 'Much as you do, sir,' returned the old man, with his hands under opposite cuffs of his loose sleeves, as he stood at the table, deferentially observant of the master's face.

column2: 'May I take the liberty to say something?'
column3: 'May I take the liberty to say something?'

column2: 'You may,' Fledgeby graciously conceded.
column3: 'You may,' Fledgeby graciously conceded.

column2: 'Do you not, sir--without intending it--of a surety without intending it--sometimes mingle the character I fairly earn in your employment, with the character which it is your policy that I should bear?'
column3: 'Do you not, sir-without intending it-of a surety without intending it-sometimes mingle the character I fairly earn in your employment, with the character which it is your policy that I should bear?'

column2: 'I don't find it worth my while to cut things so fine as to go into the inquiry,' Fascination coolly answered.
column3: 'I don't find it worth my while to cut things so fine as to go into the inquiry,' Fascination coolly answered.

column2: 'Not in justice?'
column3: 'Not in justice?'

column2: 'Bother justice!' said Fledgeby.
column3: 'Bother justice!' said Fledgeby.

column2: 'Not in generosity?'
column3: 'Not in generosity?'

column2: 'Jews and generosity!' said Fledgeby.
column3: 'Jews and generosity!' said Fledgeby.

column2: 'That's a good connexion!
column3: 'That's a good connexion!

column2: Bring out your vouchers, and don't talk Jerusalem palaver.'
column3: Bring out your vouchers, and don't talk Jerusalem palaver.'

column2: The vouchers were produced, and for the next half-hour Mr Fledgeby concentrated his sublime attention on them.
column3: The vouchers were produced, and for the next half hour Mr Fledgeby concentrated his sublime attention on them.

column2: They and the accounts were all found correct, and the books and the papers resumed their places in the bag.
column3: They and the accounts were all found correct, and the books and the papers resumed their places in the bag.

column2: 'Next,' said Fledgeby, 'concerning that bill-broking branch of the business; the branch I like best.
column3: 'Next,' said Fledgeby, 'concerning that bill broking branch of the business; the branch I like best.

column2: What queer bills are to be bought, and at what prices?
column3: What queer bills are to be bought, and at what prices?

column2: You have got your list of what's in the market?'
column3: You have got your list of what's in the market?'

column2: 'Sir, a long list,' replied Riah, taking out a pocket-book, and selecting from its contents a folded paper, which, being unfolded, became a sheet of foolscap covered with close writing.
column3: 'Sir, a long list,' replied Riah, taking out a pocket book, and selecting from its contents a folded paper, which, being unfolded, became a sheet of foolscap covered with close writing.

column2: 'Whew!' whistled Fledgeby, as he took it in his hand.
column3: 'Whew!' whistled Fledgeby, as he took it in his hand.

column2: 'Queer Street is full of lodgers just at present!
column3: 'Queer Street is full of lodgers just at present!

column2: These are to be disposed of in parcels; are they?'
column3: These are to be disposed of in parcels; are they?'

column2: 'In parcels as set forth,' returned the old man, looking over his master's shoulder; 'or the lump.'
column3: 'In parcels as set forth,' returned the old man, looking over his master's shoulder; 'or the lump.'

column2: 'Half the lump will be waste-paper, one knows beforehand,' said Fledgeby. 'Can you get it at waste-paper price?
column3: 'Half the lump will be waste paper, one knows beforehand,' said Fledgeby. 'Can you get it at waste paper price?

column2: That's the question.'
column3: That's the question.'

column2: Riah shook his head, and Fledgeby cast his small eyes down the list. They presently began to twinkle, and he no sooner became conscious of their twinkling, than he looked up over his shoulder at the grave face above him, and moved to the chimney-piece.
column3: Riah shook his head, and Fledgeby cast his small eyes down the list. They presently began to twinkle, and he no sooner became conscious of their twinkling, than he looked up over his shoulder at the grave face above him, and moved to the chimney piece.

column2: Making a desk of it, he stood there with his back to the old man, warming his knees, perusing the list at his leisure, and often returning to some lines of it, as though they were particularly interesting.
column3: Making a desk of it, he stood there with his back to the old man, warming his knees, perusing the list at his leisure, and often returning to some lines of it, as though they were particularly interesting.

column2: At those times he glanced in the chimney-glass to see what note the old man took of him.
column3: At those times he glanced in the chimney glass to see what note the old man took of him.

column2: He took none that could be detected, but, aware of his employer's suspicions, stood with his eyes on the ground.
column3: He took none that could be detected, but, aware of his employer's suspicions, stood with his eyes on the ground.

column2: Mr Fledgeby was thus amiably engaged when a step was heard at the outer door, and the door was heard to open hastily.
column3: Mr Fledgeby was thus amiably engaged when a step was heard at the outer door, and the door was heard to open hastily.

column2: 'Hark!
column3: 'Hark!

column2: That's your doing, you Pump of Israel,' said Fledgeby; 'you can't have shut it.' Then the step was heard within, and the voice of Mr Alfred Lammle called aloud, 'Are you anywhere here, Fledgeby?' To which Fledgeby, after cautioning Riah in a low voice to take his cue as it should be given him, replied, 'Here I am!' and opened his bedroom door.
column3: That's your doing, you Pump of Israel,' said Fledgeby; 'you can't have shut it.' Then the step was heard within, and the voice of Mr Alfred Lammle called aloud, 'Are you anywhere here, Fledgeby?' To which Fledgeby, after cautioning Riah in a low voice to take his cue as it should be given him, replied, 'Here I am!' and opened his bedroom door.

column2: 'Come in!' said Fledgeby.
column3: 'Come in!' said Fledgeby.

column2: 'This gentleman is only Pubsey and Co. of Saint Mary Axe, that I am trying to make terms for an unfortunate friend with in a matter of some dishonoured bills.
column3: 'This gentleman is only Pubsey and Co. of Saint Mary Axe, that I am trying to make terms for an unfortunate friend with in a matter of some dishonoured bills.

column2: But really Pubsey and Co. are so strict with their debtors, and so hard to move, that I seem to be wasting my time.
column3: But really Pubsey and Co. are so strict with their debtors, and so hard to move, that I seem to be wasting my time.

column2: Can't I make ANY terms with you on my friend's part, Mr Riah?'
column3: Can't I make ANY terms with you on my friend's part, Mr Riah?'

column2: 'I am but the representative of another, sir,' returned the Jew in a low voice.
column3: 'I am but the representative of another, sir,' returned the Jew in a low voice.

column2: 'I do as I am bidden by my principal.
column3: 'I do as I am bidden by my principal.

column2: It is not my capital that is invested in the business.
column3: It is not my capital that is invested in the business.

column2: It is not my profit that arises therefrom.'
column3: It is not my profit that arises therefrom.'

column2: 'Ha ha!' laughed Fledgeby.
column3: 'Ha ha!' laughed Fledgeby.

column2: 'Lammle?'
column3: 'Lammle?'

column2: 'Ha ha!' laughed Lammle. 'Yes.
column3: 'Ha ha!' laughed Lammle. 'Yes.

column2: Of course.
column3: Of course.

column2: We know.'
column3: We know.'

column2: 'Devilish good, ain't it, Lammle?' said Fledgeby, unspeakably amused by his hidden joke.
column3: 'Devilish good, ain't it, Lammle?' said Fledgeby, unspeakably amused by his hidden joke.

column2: 'Always the same, always the same!' said Lammle. 'Mr--'
column3: 'Always the same, always the same!' said Lammle. 'Mr-'

column2: 'Riah, Pubsey and Co.
column3: 'Riah, Pubsey and Co.

column2: Saint Mary Axe,' Fledgeby put in, as he wiped away the tears that trickled from his eyes, so rare was his enjoyment of his secret joke.
column3: Saint Mary Axe,' Fledgeby put in, as he wiped away the tears that trickled from his eyes, so rare was his enjoyment of his secret joke.

column2: 'Mr Riah is bound to observe the invariable forms for such cases made and provided,' said Lammle.
column3: 'Mr Riah is bound to observe the invariable forms for such cases made and provided,' said Lammle.

column2: 'He is only the representative of another!' cried Fledgeby. 'Does as he is told by his principal!
column3: 'He is only the representative of another!' cried Fledgeby. 'Does as he is told by his principal!

column2: Not his capital that's invested in the business.
column3: Not his capital that's invested in the business.

column2: Oh, that's good!
column3: Oh, that's good!

column2: Ha ha ha ha!' Mr Lammle joined in the laugh and looked knowing; and the more he did both, the more exquisite the secret joke became for Mr Fledgeby.
column3: Ha ha ha ha!' Mr Lammle joined in the laugh and looked knowing; and the more he did both, the more exquisite the secret joke became for Mr Fledgeby.

column2: 'However,' said that fascinating gentleman, wiping his eyes again, 'if we go on in this way, we shall seem to be almost making game of Mr Riah, or of Pubsey and Co.
column3: 'However,' said that fascinating gentleman, wiping his eyes again, 'if we go on in this way, we shall seem to be almost making game of Mr Riah, or of Pubsey and Co.

column2: Saint Mary Axe, or of somebody: which is far from our intention.
column3: Saint Mary Axe, or of somebody: which is far from our intention.

column2: Mr Riah, if you would have the kindness to step into the next room for a few moments while I speak with Mr Lammle here, I should like to try to make terms with you once again before you go.'
column3: Mr Riah, if you would have the kindness to step into the next room for a few moments while I speak with Mr Lammle here, I should like to try to make terms with you once again before you go.'

column2: The old man, who had never raised his eyes during the whole transaction of Mr Fledgeby's joke, silently bowed and passed out by the door which Fledgeby opened for him.
column3: The old man, who had never raised his eyes during the whole transaction of Mr Fledgeby's joke, silently bowed and passed out by the door which Fledgeby opened for him.

column2: Having closed it on him, Fledgeby returned to Lammle, standing with his back to the bedroom fire, with one hand under his coat-skirts, and all his whiskers in the other.
column3: Having closed it on him, Fledgeby returned to Lammle, standing with his back to the bedroom fire, with one hand under his coat skirts, and all his whiskers in the other.

column2: 'Halloa!' said Fledgeby. 'There's something wrong!'
column3: 'Halloa!' said Fledgeby. 'There's something wrong!'

column2: 'How do you know it?' demanded Lammle.
column3: 'How do you know it?' demanded Lammle.

column2: 'Because you show it,' replied Fledgeby in unintentional rhyme.
column3: 'Because you show it,' replied Fledgeby in unintentional rhyme.

column2: 'Well then; there is,' said Lammle; 'there IS something wrong; the whole thing's wrong.'
column3: 'Well then; there is,' said Lammle; 'there IS something wrong; the whole thing's wrong.'

column2: 'I say!' remonstrated Fascination very slowly, and sitting down with his hands on his knees to stare at his glowering friend with his back to the fire.
column3: 'I say!' remonstrated Fascination very slowly, and sitting down with his hands on his knees to stare at his glowering friend with his back to the fire.

column2: 'I tell you, Fledgeby,' repeated Lammle, with a sweep of his right arm, 'the whole thing's wrong.
column3: 'I tell you, Fledgeby,' repeated Lammle, with a sweep of his right arm, 'the whole thing's wrong.

column2: The game's up.'
column3: The game's up.'

column2: 'What game's up?' demanded Fledgeby, as slowly as before, and more sternly.
column3: 'What game's up?' demanded Fledgeby, as slowly as before, and more sternly.

column2: 'THE game.
column3: 'THE game.

column2: OUR game.
column3: OUR game.

column2: Read that.'
column3: Read that.'

column2: Fledgeby took a note from his extended hand and read it aloud.
column3: Fledgeby took a note from his extended hand and read it aloud.

column2: 'Alfred Lammle, Esquire.
column3: 'Alfred Lammle, Esquire.

column2: Sir: Allow Mrs Podsnap and myself to express our united sense of the polite attentions of Mrs Alfred Lammle and yourself towards our daughter, Georgiana.
column3: Sir: Allow Mrs Podsnap and myself to express our united sense of the polite attentions of Mrs Alfred Lammle and yourself towards our daughter, Georgiana.

column2: Allow us also, wholly to reject them for the future, and to communicate our final desire that the two families may become entire strangers.
column3: Allow us also, wholly to reject them for the future, and to communicate our final desire that the two families may become entire strangers.

column2: I have the honour to be, Sir, your most obedient and very humble servant, JOHN PODSNAP.' Fledgeby looked at the three blank sides of this note, quite as long and earnestly as at the first expressive side, and then looked at Lammle, who responded with another extensive sweep of his right arm.
column3: I have the honour to be, Sir, your most obedient and very humble servant, john p o d s n a p.' Fledgeby looked at the three blank sides of this note, quite as long and earnestly as at the first expressive side, and then looked at Lammle, who responded with another extensive sweep of his right arm.

column2: 'Whose doing is this?' said Fledgeby.
column3: 'Whose doing is this?' said Fledgeby.

column2: 'Impossible to imagine,' said Lammle.
column3: 'Impossible to imagine,' said Lammle.

column2: 'Perhaps,' suggested Fledgeby, after reflecting with a very discontented brow, 'somebody has been giving you a bad character.'
column3: 'Perhaps,' suggested Fledgeby, after reflecting with a very discontented brow, 'somebody has been giving you a bad character.'

column2: 'Or you,' said Lammle, with a deeper frown.
column3: 'Or you,' said Lammle, with a deeper frown.

column2: Mr Fledgeby appeared to be on the verge of some mutinous expressions, when his hand happened to touch his nose.
column3: Mr Fledgeby appeared to be on the verge of some mutinous expressions, when his hand happened to touch his nose.

column2: A certain remembrance connected with that feature operating as a timely warning, he took it thoughtfully between his thumb and forefinger, and pondered; Lammle meanwhile eyeing him with furtive eyes.

column2: 'Mr Fledgeby,' said Lammle, in a bullying tone, 'am I to understand that you in any way reflect upon me, or hint dissatisfaction with me, in this affair?'
column3: 'Mr Fledgeby,' said Lammle, in a bullying tone, 'am I to understand that you in any way reflect upon me, or hint dissatisfaction with me, in this affair?'

column2: 'No,' said Fledgeby; 'provided you have brought my promissory note in your pocket, and now hand it over.'

column2: 'NOW, Mr Fledgeby,' said Lammle, as before; 'am I to understand that you in any way reflect upon me, or hint dissatisfaction with me, in this affair?'

column2: 'Fledgeby, my hand.'

column2: And in the most friendly manner, let me mention one thing more.

column2: I don't know what your circumstances are, and I don't ask.

column2: Many men are liable to be involved at times, and you may be, or you may not be.

column2: But whatever you do, Lammle, don't--don't--don't, I beg of you--ever fall into the hands of Pubsey and Co. in the next room, for they are grinders.
column3: But whatever you do, Lammle, don't-don't-don't, I beg of you-ever fall into the hands of Pubsey and Co. in the next room, for they are grinders.

column2: Regular flayers and grinders, my dear Lammle,' repeated Fledgeby with a peculiar relish, 'and they'll skin you by the inch, from the nape of your neck to the sole of your foot, and grind every inch of your skin to tooth-powder. You have seen what Mr Riah is.

column2: Never fall into his hands, Lammle, I beg of you as a friend!'
column3: Never fall into his hands, Lammle, I beg of you as a friend!'

column2: 'You have a pair of whiskers, Lammle, which I never liked,' murmured Fledgeby, 'and which money can't produce; you are boastful of your manners and your conversation; you wanted to pull my nose, and you have let me in for a failure, and your wife says I am the cause of it.

column3: Having thus relieved his noble mind, he collected the legs of the Turkish trousers, straightened himself on his knees, and called out to Riah in the next room, 'Halloa, you sir!' column2: 'Now, old 'un,' proceeded Fledgeby, when he had had his laugh out, 'you'll buy up these lots that I mark with my pencil--there's a tick there, and a tick there, and a tick there--and I wager two-pence you'll afterwards go on squeezing those Christians like the Jew you are.
column3: 'Now, old 'un,' proceeded Fledgeby, when he had had his laugh out, 'you'll buy up these lots that I mark with my pencil-there's a tick there, and a tick there, and a tick there-and I wager two pence you'll afterwards go on squeezing those Christians like the Jew you are.

column2: Now, next you'll want a cheque--or you'll say you want it, though you've capital enough somewhere, if one only knew where, but you'd be peppered and salted and grilled on a gridiron before you'd own to it--and that cheque I'll write.'

column2: 'Is she in the house I pay rent and taxes for in Saint Mary Axe?' demanded Fledgeby.

column2: 'Is she in your garden up atop of that house--gone up to be dead, or whatever the game is?' asked Fledgeby.

column2: 'No, sir.'

column2: 'Where is she then?'

column2: 'Sir, I have no motive but to help the helpless.'

column2: 'How I came to know, and much to esteem and to respect, this damsel, I mentioned when you saw her in my poor garden on the house-top,' said the Jew.

column2: I found her beset by a selfish and ungrateful brother, beset by an unacceptable wooer, beset by the snares of a more powerful lover, beset by the wiles of her own heart.'
column3: I found her beset by a selfish and ungrateful brother, beset by an unacceptable wooer, beset by the snares of a more powerful lover, beset by the wiles of her own heart.'

column2: 'She took to one of the chaps then?'

column2: But he was not of her station, and to marry her was not in his mind.
column3: But he was not of her station, and to marry her was not in his mind.

column2: Perils were closing round her, and the circle was fast darkening, when I--being as you have said, sir, too old and broken to be suspected of any feeling for her but a father's--stepped in, and counselled flight.
column3: Perils were closing round her, and the circle was fast darkening, when I-being as you have said, sir, too old and broken to be suspected of any feeling for her but a father's-stepped in, and counselled flight.

column2: I said, "My daughter, there are times of moral danger when the hardest virtuous resolution to form is flight, and when the most heroic bravery is flight." She answered, she had had this in her thoughts; but whither to fly without help she knew not, and there were none to help her.
column3: I said, "My daughter, there are times of moral danger when the hardest virtuous resolution to form is flight, and when the most heroic bravery is flight." She answered, she had had this in her thoughts; but whither to fly without help she knew not, and there were none to help her.

column2: I showed her there was one to help her, and it was I. And she is gone.'

column2: 'No,' said Fledgeby, 'you may toddle now, Judah, and grope about on the orders you have got.' column2: 'As to Christians,' proceeded Fledgeby, 'look out, fellow-Christians, particularly you that lodge in Queer Street!
column3: 'As to Christians,' proceeded Fledgeby, 'look out, fellow Christians, particularly you that lodge in Queer Street!

column2: I have got the run of Queer Street now, and you shall see some games there.
column3: I have got the run of Queer Street now, and you shall see some games there.

column2: To work a lot of power over you and you not know it, knowing as you think yourselves, would be almost worth laying out money upon.
column3: To work a lot of power over you and you not know it, knowing as you think yourselves, would be almost worth laying out money upon.

column2: But when it comes to squeezing a profit out of you into the bargain, it's something like!'
column3: But when it comes to squeezing a profit out of you into the bargain, it's something like!'

column2: With this apostrophe Mr Fledgeby appropriately proceeded to divest himself of his Turkish garments, and invest himself with Christian attire.
column3: With this apostrophe Mr Fledgeby appropriately proceeded to divest himself of his Turkish garments, and invest himself with Christian attire.

column2: Pending which operation, and his morning ablutions, and his anointing of himself with the last infallible preparation for the production of luxuriant and glossy hair upon the human countenance (quacks being the only sages he believed in besides usurers), the murky fog closed about him and shut him up in its sooty embrace.
column3: Pending which operation, and his morning ablutions, and his anointing of himself with the last infallible preparation for the production of luxuriant and glossy hair upon the human countenance (quacks being the only sages he believed in besides usurers), the murky fog closed about him and shut him up in its sooty embrace.

column2: If it had never let him out any more, the world would have had no irreparable loss, but could have easily replaced him from its stock on hand.
column3: If it had never let him out any more, the world would have had no irreparable loss, but could have easily replaced him from its stock on hand.

column2: Chapter 2
column3: Chapter two

column2: A RESPECTED FRIEND IN A NEW ASPECT
column3: A RESPECTED FRIEND IN A NEW ASPECT

column2: In the evening of this same foggy day when the yellow window-blind of Pubsey and Co. was drawn down upon the day's work, Riah the Jew once more came forth into Saint Mary Axe.
column3: In the evening of this same foggy day when the yellow window blind of Pubsey and Co. was drawn down upon the day's work, Riah the Jew once more came forth into Saint Mary Axe.

column2: But this time he carried no bag, and was not bound on his master's affairs.
column3: But this time he carried no bag, and was not bound on his master's affairs.

column2: He passed over London Bridge, and returned to the Middlesex shore by that of Westminster, and so, ever wading through the fog, waded to the doorstep of the dolls' dressmaker.
column3: He passed over London Bridge, and returned to the Middlesex shore by that of Westminster, and so, ever wading through the fog, waded to the doorstep of the dolls' dressmaker.
